overview.heading: What is Consul?
overview.body: Consul is a service networking solution that enables teams to manage secure network connectivity between services, across on-prem, hybrid cloud, and multi-cloud environments and runtimes. Consul offers service discovery, service mesh, identity-based authorization, L7 traffic management, and secure service-to-service encryption.

get_started.body: Learn how to use Consul for service discovery and service mesh operations.

blocks.heading: Introduction to Consul: Architecture and Concepts

cards.heading: Control plane architecture
cards.body: Consul provides a control plane that enables you to register, access, and secure services deployed across your network.

cards.heading: Data plane architecture
cards.body: Consul can deploy gateways and sidecar proxies in an application's data plane to help you secure, observe, and manage application traffic.

cards.heading: Concept: Consul catalog
cards.body: The Consul catalog API tracks registered services and their locations for both service discovery and service mesh use cases.

cards.heading: Concept: Cluster consensus
cards.body: Consul ensures a consistent state using the Raft protocol. A quorum, or a majority of server agents with one leader, agree to state changes before committing to the state log.

cards.heading: Concept: Gossip communication
cards.body: Consul agents manage membership in datacenters and WAN federations using the Serf protocol, also called gossip communication.

cards.heading: Consul editions and releases
cards.body: Consul releases include Enterprise and Community editions. Additional tool binaries for managing Consul on specific runtimes and cloud providers is also available.

cards.heading: How to install Consul
cards.body: Install Consul to get started with service discovery and service mesh. Follow the installation instructions to download the precompiled binary, or use Go to compile from source.

cards.heading: Run Consul in developer mode
cards.body: Consul can deploy gateways and sidecar proxies in an application's data plane to help you secure, observe, and manage application traffic.

cards.heading: Explore the Consul HTTP API
cards.body: The Consul HTTP API is a RESTful interface for Consul that exposes endpoints for both Consul operations and service networking functions that return JSON payloads.

cards.heading: Explore the Consul CLI
cards.body: TThe Consul CLI is a wrapper for the HTTP API that allows you to interact with Consul from a terminal session.

cards.heading: Explore the Consul UI
cards.body: The Consul UI allows you to interact with Consul using a browser-based graphical user interface.

cards.heading: Identity in Consul
cards.body: In a datacenter, Consul uses identity to associate agents, configurations, and services on different nodes that may have different names but are otherwise identical.

cards.heading: Consul agent basics
cards.body: The Consul agent is a long running daemon that operates on a node. It is a core unit of Consul operations.

cards.heading: Service and health check basics
cards.body: Consul agents require service definitions in order to register services into the Consul catalog.

cards.heading: Configuration entry basics
cards.body: Configuration entries explicitly define many of Consul's security, traffic, and cluster management behaviors.

cards.heading: Consul Terraform provider basics
cards.body: You can use the official Terraform provider to configure your Consul cluster's ACLs, configuration entries, intentions, and more.
